I'm on the Senate floor right now to tell the stories of people in Connecticut whose health care would be thrown into chaos if the Republican lawsuit to overturn the ACA is successful. Tune in to watch  on C-SPAN 2.

7/ Bottom line: people are afraid. The complete obliteration of the ACA with nothing to replace it would be devastating. And there is no way that the Trump administration and Congressional Republicans can pick back up the pieces if this lawsuit is successful.

6/ John from Middletown - "I'm a cancer survivor and a computer science student. I desperately want to work at a startup, but I would be terrified. All because I am scared that in the near future the ACA will be repealed and I would be left without insurance."

5/ Kat from Weatogue- "The protections the ACA gives my family concerning pre-existing conditions are how we are able to receive adequate medical care. Without those protections, I would have to choose between my medical care and my family‚Äôs ability to eat and live in our house."
4/ Michelle from Brookfield - "I am a survivor of ovarian cancer (twice). If the insurance company had been allowed to not cover the second occurrence, I would probably not be here today."

3/ Claudia from Coventry - ‚ÄúI have survived breast cancer (five years in June), and I was diagnosed just as my COBRA coverage was expiring. If I hadn't had coverage through the ACA, my retirement savings would have been wiped out.‚Äù

2/ Becky, from Storrs - ‚ÄúIf the Affordable Care Act is struck down, and insurance companies are allowed to kick people with pre-existing conditions off of their parents‚Äô insurance, we'd lose everything. We would have to declare bankruptcy.‚Äù

1/ THREAD: Over the past few months, I've heard from hundreds of people in Connecticut about how the ACA has impacted their lives. They are terrified that the GOP lawsuit to overturn the ACA will succeed. Here are just a few stories of #WhatsAtStake for families in our state.

As you celebrate the 4th, remember that many of us are here (including me) bc up until 100 years ago, America essentially had open borders. My ancestors fled poverty in Europe and showed up here unannounced. They weren‚Äôt locked in cages, they were welcomed by a generous nation.

Met Janet and Nick out for a walk on a beautiful night in Woodbury. Health care costs are hurting Nick‚Äôs small business. He‚Äôs not sold on Medicare for All yet but he knows something has to change. I told them about my Choose Medicare Act and they were intrigued. #WalkCT
5/ and I understand I might get kicked off twitter for this kind of heresy.

4/ point is simple - too often we judge people based on their politics. Ds to it to Rs. Rs do it to Ds. But you know what - we are all mostly really good people. There are exceptions, sure, but we‚Äôd be a lot better off if we didn‚Äôt assume we know somebody bc of who they vote for.

3/ Then 20 min later I‚Äôm laboring up a huge hill and one of the guys rumbles up next to me in his pickup. Hands me a cold bottle of water thru the window and says ‚Äúthought I might find you. figured you needed this‚Äù.

2/ as I‚Äôm leaving I ask how the job is going. They say their real job is somewhere else. This is an emergency job they are doing as a favor. Elderly lady is getting out of hospital and needs a ramp installed so she can come home.

1/ little moments like this are why I love the walk across CT. Stopped to say hi to some guys working on a house. Immediately clear these are Trump guys. Taxes are too high, welfare cheats ruining the country, etc. We go at it for 5 min or so.
